Question: How to write text file in java: :I am new to java and I am writing coding for automation in Selenium. I want to know is it possible to write a text file throughout the java program till end of the program. I have tried to write a text file using bufferedWriter.write(). First three lines are writing and after that it is not at all writing any text. I have tried flush. My question is,do we have possibility to open file at starting of the program and write lines when ever we need in the middle of the program and as many number of lines and close the file end of the program?If possible, request to share any same code. I am fine with any file write method (File Writer, Buffered writer, file output stream)
Please using this api: PrintWriter.write.
Answer:

<<<code>>>: $CODE

Question: How to write text file in java: :I am new to java and I am writing coding for automation in Selenium. I want to know is it possible to write a text file throughout the java program till end of the program. I have tried to write a text file using bufferedWriter.write(). First three lines are writing and after that it is not at all writing any text. I have tried flush. My question is,do we have possibility to open file at starting of the program and write lines when ever we need in the middle of the program and as many number of lines and close the file end of the program?If possible, request to share any same code. I am fine with any file write method (File Writer, Buffered writer, file output stream)
Please using this api: PrintWriter.write.
Answer: <<<api>>>: PrintWriter
<<<code>>>: 
```java
PrintWriter writer = new PrintWriter("your_file_path", "UTF-8");
writer.println("Your text");
writer.close();
```
<<<explanation>>>: PrintWriter is a class in Java which is used to print formatted representations of objects to a text-output stream. It is mainly used for writing text to a file. The PrintWriter class can automatically flush the output.

If you want to write to a file throughout the program, you can create a PrintWriter object at the start of your program and use its write method to write to the file whenever you need. When you are done writing, you can simply call the close method to close the file.

Here is an example:
```java
import java.io.PrintWriter;
import java.io.FileOutputStream;
import java.io.IOException;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try {
            PrintWriter writer = new PrintWriter(new FileOutputStream("your_file_path", true), true);
            writer.println("Your text");
            // You can write as many lines as you want
            writer.println("More text");
            writer.close();
        } catch (IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}
```
In this example, the PrintWriter is created with a FileOutputStream that opens a connection to the file "your_file_path". The second parameter to FileOutputStream is a boolean that determines whether to append to the file or not. If you want to append to the file, set it to true. If you want to overwrite the file, set it to false.

The PrintWriter is created with a boolean that determines whether to automatically flush the output each time you call println. If you want the output to be flushed automatically, set it to true. If you don't want the output to be flushed automatically, set it to false.

You can call println as many times as you want to write lines to the file. When you are done writing, you can call close to close the file.

Please replace "your_file_path" with the actual path to your file.
